advice_to_mgmt: Please continue to focus on the importance of culture. There are a lot of hot companies out there, and while Eventbrite is one of them, we need all the competitive advantages we can get in terms of finding the best talent.

review_title: Truly wonderful company to work for - especially for new moms
pros:
Eventbrite is the most genuinely "people first" company I've ever worked for. From the top down there's a huge emphasis on hiring the right people and investing in them to keep them around for a long time. It's the first job I've had where I can picture my career growth very long term, and plan to be here for as long as I can.

The totally unique amazing thing they have (that I've never heard of another company, let along tech company) having is such amazing support for new moms. They were great about supporting my maternity leave and transition back and, this is the kicker, they have the most amazing "Mom Rooms" ever. There are two rooms that both have hospital grade pumps (!!!) that they give you personal parts for. There's a fridge, a cushy arm chair, and basically everything you need to be a breastfeeding and working Mom. It's out of control awesome. It's made the challenge of breastfeeding while working full time much easier, and made me much less nervous to come back.

There are a lot of other great perks (great catering, a smoothy bar with two vitamixes, yoga and massage). A lot of other tech companies have these but I feel like the over riding difference is the clear investment in employee wellness and work life balance.
cons: The only thing to mention is that salaries are a shade lower than some similar tech companies. I can say pretty confidently that the benefits, perks, and flexibility compensate almost entirely for the difference.

pros: This company is forward-thnking and on the brink of something amazing. In my first 30 minutes as an employee, I felt more welcome than anywhere else I have ever worked. The benefits are amazing and having the ability to work from home has been a life saver for me. I also love that there is open communication from the top as well as across teams.
cons: In working from home, I sometimes feel disconnected. We do have team meetings where we come together, but there is something to be said for in-office bonding as well. This is also a very young company, and by that I mean that most of the people here are young, including leadership. Nothing wrong with that except that as an older adult, I sometimes feel I am unable to relate.
advice_to_mgmt: Love the benefits you provide; they are awesome and thank you! Career advancement opportunities are vague. I have no clue what my career path could be with Eventbrite. We need more transparency here and clearer communication.

pros: Great benefits and everyone is happy
cons: there's so much happiness that you get pressured to be happy when sometimes might not be.

review_title: The most genuine coworkers and supportive environment that I've ever encountered.
pros:
* Colleagues are supportive and always willing to help you learn a new skill or contribute their expertise to a project. People are not territorial or competitive at all. There is team spirit in the truest sense (not just as a catchphrase).
* Everyone is genuinely friendly and cares about you as a person. I've made "real life" friends with many of the people I've worked with. Going to work is actually fun! At the same time, there is absolutely no forced socialization or expectation that you need to "fit in" -- as a general rule everyone is very accepting and welcoming.
* The degree of transparency is very high -- founders have weekly chats with the entire company where any question can be asked and will be answered. There is a minimum of office politics.
* Good work-life balance: unlimited PTO, managers encourage work life balance and there isn't a culture of staying in the office until midnight.

I've worked at 3 different companies before this, and can honestly say that Eventbrite is my favorite by far.
cons: Compensation tends to be on the modest side, although in line with industry standards. Also balanced out by the fact that we get unlimited PTO, good work life balance, etc -- versus other places with higher compensation but a cutthroat work culture.

pros: Great culture, awesome perks & benefits, good training
cons: Office not large enough to hold employees. Working from home is great but I'd like a little more flexibility.
advice_to_mgmt: We are in a new office so there was some question as to who are managers were in the beginning. It would have been nice to have had the manager walk with us through training.

review_title: Enjoyed working for Google, but LOVE working for Eventbrite even more!
pros:
I've been at the company, full time, for several years - here goes:

Transparency - I love how everything is communicated to the employees and how often updates are sent out. This manifests in company all hands meetings, emails, exposure to Kevin (CEO) and Julia (President) since they sit at a regular table on the main floor like all other employees, and even a "heart to hartz" where you can ask them any question about the company, goals, etc.

Leadership - Management is pretty awesome and the board, executive staff, and VPs are all very smart and make great decisions. Also doesnt hurt that Julia reaaaaaally cares about people and office morale and makes sure that "wellness" is a top company priority.

Equity/company success - I believe the company will do really well as it scales internationally and across many verticals. Its pretty nice to have equity in a soon-to-IPO company that will be massively successful.

Growth opportunities - People move around all the time. If you're a hard worker you can jump to other positions either by moving teams, or being promoted. Its awesome how Eventbrite helps its employees do what they love.

Perks - free food/snacks/beer, dogs in office, massage, yoga, acupuncture, nap room, games room, tons of offsites, opportunities to join groups for sports or similar interests, great medical/dental, wellness and transportation stipend, unlimited vacation days via a "take the time you need" approach, and best of all - SMART PEOPLE that are humble and fun to work with (yes, I hang out with my team outside of work because I enjoy their company!)
cons: I've been at the company for several years and have seen how people who underperform get fired (which is fair to do), but the manner in which its communicated to employees/team members can be done better.
advice_to_mgmt:
Please start matching 401k.

Because Eventbrite is a growing company, its people are growing professionally with it. Eventbrite has been hiring very smart, motivated, and cool people to work with but then when it was time to promote them to be managers - they were first time managers that had never managed people and didnt know how to do so. I think theres more training going on now so please keep the training going to ensure managers know how to lead effectively.

pros:
Best work culture I've experienced in my life. Everyone is so friendly, positive, and loves their job/this company.
Great benefits/perks, great food, amazing office.
Management treats you like an adult and expects you to act like one - mutual respect is the norm.
cons: If you don't want a big company with lots of loud personalities, this may not be the place for you. As a friendly/talkative people-person, however, this has not been an issue for me!

pros: Eventbrite really brings to life the "Make it Happen Spirit!" Believe me, this is not your average company! Kevin & Julia are truly passionate about their customers and employees alike. Between generous benefits, an awesome work space, supportive staff and of course many other awesome perks (shhhhhh), Eventbrite has brought a whole new meaning to "love brand!"
cons: Hands down, just way too many amazing people in one office...it really should be a crime.

review_title: A big company that still hold onto it's humility
pros: It's great being able to work with a company that hasn't grown to large that they forget who's important in the day to day functions of the business. Eventbrite has a great culture of independence and encourages employees to be unique. However, they actually make you feel welcome.
cons: They don't have a 401-K matching plan yet; but I can understand as they're still growing. Hopefully the new Nashville office can grow to a size that allows those who don't want to work from the option. Sign-up lists aren't very inviting.
advice_to_mgmt: So far, so great!

review_title: New Part-Time CSR Employee in Nashville
pros: The people, the culture, the product, ALL THE THINGS. The hiring process was very efficient and they did not waste time asking the same questions different ways, repeatedly. They really know who they are looking for and seek them out. Persnoally, I feel really at home here and everyone is very warm and supportive. Their transparency really makes you feel like you're WITH them all the way. Also, there are snacks.

advice_to_mgmt: To our jumpers / seeders in Nashville, keep being awesome.

review_title: Make it happen" people flourish in the Briteland
pros:

review_title: Better than most places to work
pros: The Founders have a vision and they are going to get us there. They drive employees and while sometimes we have to bring them back to reality, its the visionaries (not the rational ppl out there) that go big. The new office is really nice and convenient to get to, I never have to think about what to eat (even if the food isn't always what I would pick....) and if there is something you need (resource, equipment, etc) to get your job done better/faster/etc. you can get it. Its nice not to have effectiveness limited by tight budget of limited cash flows. I also appreciate the transparency and tone of leadership towards the rest of the company. Kevin and Julia are completely approachable and WANT to hear what the employees (at any level) have to say.
cons: This is a real company with big goals and huge initiatives on tight timelines, ie means there is a lot of work to get done and not a lot of time to do it. Just because this is a shiny happy start-up that treats people well, employees or potential employees need to know while people certainly play hard around here, working hard until your job is "done" is the expectation (ie this is not a 9-5 gig). This is not truly a con, however, i think its important to point out that the perception of a startup always being "fun fun fun" is not the reality. This is still a job and it is still work people!
advice_to_mgmt: Seriously, it is time to start with 401k matching...

Many people left Apple to be apart of Eventbrite because our Founders understand that if the employees are well cared for then they will care for the customers and it will come naturally!
advice_to_mgmt: NEVER FORGET TO TAKE CARE OF YOUR EMPLOYEES! HIRE GREAT PEOPLE AND YOU WILL HAVE THE EASIEST JOB YET!

pros:

As the company grows, leadership is getting really good at structuring career progression for its employees. In the year that I have been here, I've seen and experienced these changes first hand and it's been awesome. The company values and responds well to all feedback, which should encourage employees to speak up and work for what they want. Tons of growth potential and the roles are lined up to launch people forward and to the top.

The new office is a dream as well!
cons: Hoping 401k matching is in the near future ...
advice_to_mgmt: Keep working on making this team the best one out there with training, clear career paths and a collaborative environment.

pros: Great company. Great culture. Company will be successful.
cons:
Career Progression:
In sales there is no real career progression. As you advance, the quota gets larger, commission rates decrease, and the prospect quality / deal sizes stay the same.

Leadership:
In the past year, the leadership has shifted the culture in Sales. It's gone from a very entrepreneurial environment to a heavily micro-managed team. I've got this as a con, as only a certain type of sales persona enjoys being micro-managed.

Commission:
If you do decide to go to Eventbrite, be ready to reconcile every paycheck, as they are still ironing out tracking deals. Every month, my commission came in short and had to be corrected. I surfaced the issue and was told to keep reconciling until they got a better handle on tracking. Hopefully this has been corrected.
advice_to_mgmt:
Advice to Sales management - Listen to the team. If a leader is having a toxic effect on the team, address the issue.

Advice to Company - Stay focused and invest time understanding the market.

pros: Eventbrite has a lot of great training resources. The Sales Team especially puts in a lot of extra effort to provide training tools and one of one time to really understand how to be successful in the role.
cons: Eventbrite is very ambitious when it comes to going after new markets. This means that the quota expectations are extremeley agressive.

pros: The best thing about working at Eventbrite is the truly lived philosophy of engaging employees with the business in real and meaningful ways on a daily basis. cons: I can't really think of any cons that go beyond the usual small workplace problems. review_title: Problems at Vancouver office potentially saved by Eventbrite brand, but history of toxic culture and high turnover
pros:
- Eventbrite has a positive brand and culture and will likely try to improve local reputation.

- Fun space to work in: events.
cons:
Do extra research and reference checks if you're looking at a job at this office. While Eventbrite has a workplace brand of being inclusive, diverse, and supportive, this office has a reputation of something quite different. The Eventbrite Vancouver office came from the acquisition of a Vancouver startup called Picatic. That team and its leadership are still intact there, but was wrought with high turnover and toxic workplace culture for years. Here are some specific examples:

- Extremely high turnover and so many disgruntled former employees. In the last 2 years leading to the Picatic acquisition by Eventbrite, for example about 70% of the people hired to do sales, marketing, or support (the half of the company not coding full time on the core product) left in frustration or were abruptly fired. You'd never get a genuinely convincing reason why they quit or were fired, they'd never visit the office, you'd see them remove Picatic from their LinkedIn bios, you'd see them write insinuating comments around the web about it being a mediocre job, and you'd even see them leave disgruntled comments on the management team's social media posts. The origin story of the company was rarely shared because it's full of burned bridges. It was so painful.

- Not diverse, not supportive. For example, no women were hired or could be retained as employees. Many times, you would hear people's opinions be insulted out loud in front of other teams or colleagues. If an opinion wasn't the same as management's, often you would be ganged up on. Over time, everyone just started sucking up because other opinions and debate were so dangerous.

- These aren't just fixable skills, like hiring, managing, firing, defining job responsibilities, etc, but systematic problems. Also being able to say that the company was acquired (though really acqui-hired to the detriment of many people) probably only gives them validation that how they were doing things is ok, so they are unlikely to change.

- Look at roles at other offices, or just hold off 6 months and see if things and office leadership dramatically change.

cons:
Eventbrite masquerades as a "startup" when really they have been running for 11 years but still haven't sorted out some very basic business processes (like employing local HR, ensuring people get paid the right salary/commission, actually reaching profitability etc etc). Although Eventbrite celebrates & boasts of it's "startup culture" it no longer exists. In reality management want everyone to behave like they are in a big, musty old corporate machine with no diversity, no freedom / trust / autonomy, a very slow pace of change, an extremely hierarchical structure and a general "do as I say not as I do" attitude. This is a shame and a waste of the talent & loyalty of the staff that built and stuck with it over the last crucial 3-5 years or so. It's no wonder the last 12 months have seen a mass exodus of key staff members from all departments in every country Eventbrite operates.
This is a business that's lost it's direction and lost it's soul.
advice_to_mgmt:
Trust and listen to your staff. You hired them, now give them the autonomy to do their jobs without micromanagement.
Take international teams more seriously. Take the time to understand them and think of them first, not last, if global expansion is truly your goal.
Care more for your employees, don't make them feel dispensable (even if you think they are it will cost you more to have to keep hiring & training new people than make the people you have feel valued).
Value diversity - cookie-cutter teams have a short shelf life and won't learn & grow from each other.
Give people clear paths & opportunity for progression - don't promise promotions every quarter that will never arrive

Eventbrite WAS a great place to work. There was a real buzz and people were collaborating across the business towards achieving a common goal - which was making Eventbrite a great success. It was also an environment where management/leadership were supportive and it felt like we were all in it together.

However things changed...

Understandably when a company grows it needs to get more streamlined processes, systems and become accountable - it is debatable if this has happened at Eventbrite - what is becoming clear though is that the culture has taken a dive.

Leadership appears to have taken an 'us and them' approach - lots of 'have you got a minute mate, let's grab a room/go for a walk' type chats. Minimal communication. Lots of people leaving quite quickly and quite uncertain what the long game is.

Leadership seems to neglect that employees emotionally invest in a company and work hard to make it a success. To have a leader say 'tough, there are worse places to work' when raising concerns is incredibly demotivating.

A lack of trust has also crept in, management have spoken negatively about absent employees in open spaces as well as making inappropriate comments about employees personal lives. Management has also been vocal about their political views - which is fine - however the ways and means that this has been done has left quite a few feeling uncomfortable.

Inconsistent career progression

It seems that HR are quick to respond to Glassdoor reviews however the reality is that HR on the whole were unresponsive and seemed to be more focussed on the US.
advice_to_mgmt:
Don't just hire corporate men - there is a huge and diverse talent pool out there
As well as tech people Eventbrite also needs people who know the ticketing space
Get to know your teams properly
Communicate well and regularly with positive intent
If you do run things like 'culture focus groups' follow up - people participated as they want to drive positive change
Play nicely and try and minimise politics

review_title: Used to be great, has gone down hill rapidly since 2015.
pros:
Good name to have on CV
Generally hire good people (excluding management positions)
Free lunches, drinks and snacks
cons:
Recent hirings have been weighted on the corporate side, losing much of the culture which made Eventbrite a great place to work initially.
No HR in place outside the SF office, and no anonymity - if you had a grievance this would just be reported back to your manager creating a more hostile environment.
Lots of internal politics, often the person who shouts the loudest or is friends with the right person gets their way.
No career progression within UK office - no transparency or structure in place. Often promises made at interview and annual review stages which are then never acted on.
Not a transparent company despite insisting they are - really bad at communicating both at a team and company level, which creates a thriving rumour mill.
advice_to_mgmt:
Trust your staff, stop micro-managing, clock-watching and putting processes in place for the sake of it.
Involve your full company, not just the HQ, in feedback and brainstorming sessions, and think about your other markets when creating and releasing updates - not as an after thought.
Spend more time visiting other offices to understand what is going on in them - do not just trust local management who are likely spinning the story to fit their narrative.
Hire management who have industry experience, not corporates who talk fluff.
